sen.j: 大河内 正質（おおこうち まさただ、弘化元年4月11日 (旧暦)（1844年5月27日） - 明治34年（1901年）6月2日（グレゴリオ暦））は、幕末の上総国大多喜藩第9代で最後の藩主。
sen.e: Masatada OKOCHI (May 27, 1844 - June 2, 1901) was the ninth and the last lord of Otaki Domain in Kazusa Province, who lived during the end of Edo Period.
Masatada OKOCHI (May 27, 1844 - June 2, 1901) was the ninth and the last lord of Otaki Domain in Kazusa Province, who lived during the end of the Edo Period.
Masatada OKOCHI (May 27, 1844 - June 2, 1901) was the ninth and the last lord of Otaki Domain in Kazusa Province, who lived during the end of the Edo Period.

sen.j: 奏者番・若年寄・老中格。
sen.e: He served as sojaban (an official in charge of the ceremonies), wakadoshiyori (a managerial position in Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun)), and received the treatment relevant to roju (a member of shogun's council of elders).
sen.cmt: 老中格→定訳不明：received the treatment relevant to roju (a member of shogun's council of elders)としました。
sen.e: He served as sojaban (an official in charge of the ceremonies), wakadoshiyori (a managerial position in Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun)), and received the treatment relevant to roju (a member of shogun's council of elders).

He served as sojaban (an official in charge of the ceremonies), wakadoshiyori (a managerial position in Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun)), and received the treatment relevant to roju (a member of shogun's council of elders).
He was the 11th generation of the Okochi Matsudaira head family.
He was the 11th generation of the Okochi Matsudaira head family.
He was the 11th generation of the Okochi Matsudaira head family.

sen.j: 越前国鯖江藩主・間部詮勝の五男。
sen.e: He was the fifth son of Akikatsu Manabe, head of the Sabae Domain, Echizen Province.
He was the fifth son of Akikatsu Manabe, head of the Sabae Domain, Echizen Province.
He was the fifth son of Akikatsu Manabe, head of the Sabae Domain, Echizen Province.
His lawful wife was Masatomo MATSUDAIRA's daughter.
His lawful wife was Masatomo MATSUDAIRA's daughter.
His lawful wife was Masatomo MATSUDAIRA's daughter.

sen.j: 子は大河内正敏（長男）、大河内正倫（次男）、娘（小西某室）。
sen.e: His sons were Masatoshi OKOCHI (the first son) and Masatomo OKOCHI (the second son), and his daughter was the wife of a person called KONISHI.
His sons were Masatoshi OKOCHI (the first son) and Masatomo OKOCHI (the second son), and his daughter was the wife of a person called KONISHI.
His sons were Masatoshi OKOCHI (the first son) and Masatomo OKOCHI (the second son), and his daughter was the wife of a person called KONISHI.
His official court rank was Buzen no kuni no Kami (Governor of Buzen Province).
His official court rank was Buzen no kuni no Kami (Governor of Buzen Province).
His official court rank was Buzen no kuni no Kami (Governor of Buzen Province).

sen.j: 文久2年（1862年）、先代藩主・正和の婿養子として大多喜藩主の座を継ぐ。
sen.e: He succeeded to the status of the lord of Otaki Domain in 1862, after marring into the family of former lord of the domain, Masatomo.
He succeeded to the status of the lord of Otaki Domain in 1862, after marring into the family of former lord of the domain, Masatomo.
He succeeded to the status of the lord of Otaki Domain in 1862, after marring into the family of former lord of the domain, Masatomo.

sen.j: 元治元年（1864年）奏者番、慶応2年（1866年）若年寄を経て、慶応3年（1867年）12月15日、老中格となる。
sen.e: He was appointed as sojaban in 1864 and wakadoshiyori in 1867, and received the treatment relevant to roju since January 9, 1868.
sen.cmt: 慶応3年（1867年）12月15日→January 9, 1868：西暦に直しました。
sen.e: He was appointed as sojaban in 1864 and wakadoshiyori in 1867, and received the treatment relevant to roju since January 9, 1868.
He was appointed as sojaban in 1864 and wakadoshiyori in 1867, and received the treatment relevant to roju since January 9, 1868.

sen.j: 翌年1月、鳥羽伏見の戦いで、幕府側の軍を指揮するが敗北。
sen.e: In January of the same year (1868), he lead the Bakufu army in the Battle of Toba and Fushimi, but his army was defeated.
sen.cmt: 翌年1月→January of the same year (1868)：西暦にすると｢翌年」ではなくなるのでこのようにしました。
sen.e: In January of the same year (1868), he lead the Bakufu army in the Battle of Toba and Fushimi, but his army was defeated.
In January of the same year (1868), he lead the Bakufu army in the Battle of Toba and Fushimi, but his army was defeated.

sen.j: 改易され佐倉藩に預けられる。
sen.e: He underwent "kaieki" sanction (sudden dismissal and deprivation of position, privileges and properties) and was placed in custody of Sakura Domain.
He underwent "kaieki" sanction (sudden dismissal and deprivation of position, privileges and properties) and was placed in custody of Sakura Domain.
He underwent "kaieki" sanction (sudden dismissal and deprivation of position, privileges and properties) and was placed in custody of Sakura Domain.

sen.j: 同年許され所領を回復した。
sen.e: In the same year, he was pardoned and recovered his territories.
In the same year, he was pardoned and recovered his territories.
In the same year, he was pardoned and recovered his territories.

sen.j: 明治2年（1869年）、版籍奉還により大多喜藩知事に就任。
sen.e: In 1869, he was appointed to the Governor of Otaki Domain when the return of lands and people to the emperor was carried out.
In 1869, he was appointed to the Governor of Otaki Domain when the return of lands and people to the emperor was carried out.
In 1869, he was appointed to the Governor of Otaki Domain when the return of lands and people to the emperor was carried out.

sen.j: 明治4年（1871年）、廃藩置県により免官。
sen.e: In 1871, he was resigned from the governor's post due to Haihan-chiken (abolition of feudal domains and establishment of prefectures).
In 1871, he was resigned from the governor's post due to Haihan-chiken (abolition of feudal domains and establishment of prefectures).
In 1871, he was resigned from the governor's post due to Haihan-chiken (abolition of feudal domains and establishment of prefectures).

sen.j: 明治維新後は、松平姓から大河内姓に復し、子爵に列せられた。
sen.e: After the Meiji Restoration, he changed his family name from Matsudaira to his original family name, Okochi, and was conferred the title of viscount.
After the Meiji Restoration, he changed his family name from Matsudaira to his original family name, Okochi, and was conferred the title of viscount.
After the Meiji Restoration, he changed his family name from Matsudaira to his original family name, Okochi, and was conferred the title of viscount.
